Bart.Action: Shuffles forward as the hero among oppressed workers, showing resilience and presence in a harsh environment.
Leads fellow workers in a spirited, up-tempo Sinatra-style song, engaging them in a communal activity.
Feigns ignorance along with co-workers in response to overseer's patronizing demand for a stereotypical song.
Leads co-workers in an up-tempo Sinatra-style song, cleverly improvising and coordinating with them to create a musical performance that confuses overseers.
Feigns ignorance of expected songs when questioned by overseer Lyle, convincing co-workers to join the act, displaying quick thinking and social intelligence.
Responds to a harsh command from the foreman without complaint and shows camaraderie and humor with Charlie.
Expresses frustration and fear about being trapped in quicksand with Charlie, calls out for help sincerely.
Mocks the danger with Charlie by making a riddle about quicksand before showing genuine fear.
Shouts for help along with Charlie, showing a clear plea for rescue and concern for survival.
Recognizes they are sinking in quicksand and correctly identifies quicksand as the danger.
Calls for help persistently while trapped in quicksand.
Does not devise or attempt any escape plan or show practical skill to get out of quicksand.
In a desperate situation, Bart manages to grab onto the handcar despite strain and difficulty, enabling himself and Charlie to be pulled to safety.
Bart reacts angrily to the danger and Taggart’s disregard, showing frustration but not strategic behavior.
Bart and Charlie stare in amazement as Lyle skillfully tosses the rope over their heads out of reach, showing their inability to act effectively in the moment.
Grabs shovel and takes vicious practice swings with it, then smashes Taggart on the head with the shovel.
Grabs shovel, stands up, and takes vicious practice swings with it before attacking Taggart.
Smashes Taggart on the head unexpectedly, effectively stopping him.
Suggests waiting so that those who arrived earlier are executed first.
Replies politely to guard's grim humor about blindfold or after dinner mint.
Calmly negotiates the wait time at the gallows by reminding the guard that others were there before him, showing presence of mind.
Politely and wittily requests a reprieve before execution, demonstrating quick thinking and composure.
No indication of panic or loss of control while being led to execution, maintains confidence.
Begins a prayer before his execution, expressing acceptance and speaks with a tone of love rather than hatred.
Surreptitiously escapes execution while others are distracted and heads bowed in prayer.
Calmly uses a fake prayer moment to slip the noose and escape unnoticed while others are distracted.
Maintains composure under threat, carefully evades capture until confronted with a gun.
Accepts being introduced as the new sheriff despite racial prejudice and hostility from others in the room.
Sits quietly in the corner during the confrontation, showing restraint and composure.
Calmly sits in the corner after being insulted and doubted by the Governor and Lamarr, showing composure and confidence.
Does not respond to the Governor's offensive remarks, potentially maintaining control of the situation.
Takes a non-confrontational stance when challenged about his appointment, showing situational awareness.
Rides across the prairie confidently and stylishly, clearly in command of his presence and appearance.
Approaches the town as the sheriff, commanding attention and respect from townspeople.
Tips his hat in acknowledgement upon seeing the townspeople's reaction.
Makes a sarcastic comment 'Excuse me, while I whip this out' causing a woman to scream and faint.
Rides confidently into town despite initial shock from townspeople, calmly approaches speaker's platform, tips his hat in acknowledgement, and begins reading official proclamation
Uses humor with the line 'Excuse me, while I whip this out' causing a woman to scream and faint, risking alienation of crowd
Shows fear but uses a bluff to prevent violence and protect himself and others.
Uses a racial slur in a threatening context as part of a bluff.
Raises his eyebrows, showing growing awareness of impending danger.
Quickens his speech pace to assert authority as sheriff despite tension.
Whips out gun and feigns threatening self-harm to intimidate armed townspeople and de-escalate conflict.
Clearly frightened and closes eyes tightly, indicating inner fear despite outward confidence.
Urges townspeople to throw down their guns gently to avoid violence.
Threatens violent action if guns are raised again, showing readiness to use force.
Calmly commands the townspeople to throw down their guns and manages to de-escalate a violent situation.
Observes threat on the roof and directly confronts the armed man, successfully forcing him to drop the weapon.
Backs down the street slowly and confidently while maintaining control of the situation.
Attempts to run but stops immediately at a warning shot, demonstrating self-control and awareness of consequences.
Puts himself inside the jail house door slowly despite anguish, shows vulnerability by hugging himself and saying 'I love you.'
Eases himself slowly backwards to reach the jailhouse door and shuts it firmly, showing caution and control under pressure.
Expresses relief with a sigh and affection by hugging himself, indicating emotional vulnerability but also self-awareness.
Paints over the black face on the jockey ashtray, making it white.
Throws away a 'Wanted' poster of a black man, stating he has enough trouble without being chased by others.
Carefully paints the face of a black jockey ashtray white with a fine-tipped brush, showing attention to detail and skill.
Selectively posts wanted posters, choosing to exclude a black man to protect him from trouble, demonstrating thoughtful judgment and strategic thinking.
Helps prisoner Jim to his feet after noticing he's hung over.
Offers Jim food despite his refusal and warns about dangers of drinking without eating.
Engages Jim in conversation to learn his likes and offers to play chess with him.

Stops to assess the situation calmly when hearing a crash, approaches the cell, offers help to a prisoner struggling to get upright, unlocks the cell door, helps the prisoner to his feet, and offers advice about eating.
Engages the prisoner in conversation to understand his condition and interests, demonstrating social awareness and emotional intelligence.
Questions the senseless violence in town and expresses determination to find answers.
Refuses to take back a chess move, accepting consequences and asserting maturity despite showing vulnerability by sucking his thumb.
Makes a deliberate chess move acknowledging its risk and commits to facing the consequences rather than undoing it.
Expresses determination to find the reason behind the town's chaos despite lack of clues.
Pretends confidence but sucks his thumb after admitting the chess move was a mistake.
Engages in a playful game of chess, dances a little victory dance, and teases Jim lightheartedly.
Questions Jim's harmful behavior with concern: 'Hey, man, why do you do that to yourself?'
Mocks Jim slightly by threatening to write him up for the Reader's Digest as 'the most unforgettable drunk,' but in a joking way.
Challenges Jim to show a trick, showing playful competitiveness but also mutual respect.
Accuses Jim of not being the legendary Waco Kid and claims he was 'just pullin' my lariat,' indicating a teasing but friendly rapport.
Makes a checkmate move in chess with flourish and confidently declares victory.
Confidently engages in banter, demonstrating quick wit and social intelligence.
Follows Jim's instructions quickly and confidently to grab the king piece first.
Offers Jim a drink, laughs with him, and engages in friendly banter.
Jokes by imitating a harp and humorously recounting family history despite hardship.
Displays surprise showing emotional responsiveness.
Clasps his hands over the king and smiles victoriously before being surprised that the king was taken from under his hat.
Engages in friendly banter and willingly offers Jim a drink, demonstrating social ease and confidence.
Narrates his family’s story with humor and self-awareness, showing quick wit and storytelling ability.
Narrates the encounter with the Sioux and the chief with a calm, matter-of-fact tone, showing acceptance of his situation.
Shows concern for Jim by covering him with a blanket after he falls asleep.
Addresses Jim sarcastically to try to engage him but responds by taking care of him despite Jim's inattentiveness.
Creates their own wagon circle when not allowed to travel in Indians' circle.
Narrates story confidently to an uninterested (asleep) audience and handles it without frustration.
Gently places the sleeping Jim on a cot and covers him with a blanket.
Smiles and shakes his head at Jim’s good night before turning out the lamp.
Carefully puts a sleeping Jim on his cot and covers him with a blanket before going to sleep himself and turning out the lamp.
Shares his own tobacco and smokes with Jim, showing casual camaraderie.
Expresses optimism and belief in being accepted despite Jim's warning.
Quietly confident about establishing himself, showing determination but no malice.
Carefully prepares his own cigarette instead of relying on Jim's, showing self-sufficiency and attention to detail.
Confidently asserts that once he establishes himself, the townspeople will accept him, demonstrating insight into human nature and confidence in his ability to succeed.
Ignores Jim's advice warning him that the townspeople will not accept him, showing a confident but potentially risky optimism.
Greets elderly woman politely despite her insult.
Closes his eyes and shakes his head after being insulted, showing restraint.
Intervenes to stop children from bullying one boy.
Engages with children in imaginative play and helps Mongo with diving equipment.
Stops pumping water for Mongo claiming he is on a break despite Mongo still being underwater.
Politely greets elderly woman despite her insult, showing emotional control and confidence.
Responds to fight by intervening decisively and effectively, dispersing bullies and protecting victim.
Demonstrates knowledge and leadership by organizing a treasure hunt and fitting Mongo with diving gear, showing practical skills and confidence.
Stops pumping to take a break while Mongo is underwater, suggesting possible lapse in attentiveness and responsibility.
Reassures Mongo about the cost ('Don't worry about the tariff, Pal, catch you later').
Encourages Mongo to smile before being shot from the cannon.
Organizes a novelty photo event with a cannon and manages to calm and instruct Mongo effectively, demonstrating confidence and clear communication.
Accepts that Mongo has no money and lets him go without issue, showing practical flexibility.
Whistles to bring in a second cannon and operates both cannons simultaneously showing control and coordination.
Makes a humorous comparison (Mongo as smart as a '38 Buick) indicating wit and ease in stressful moments.
Dismisses Mongo's abilities and complains about lack of recognition.
Receives a pie from the elderly woman as an apology after insulting him earlier.
Acknowledges Mongo's strength with calm confidence and downplays his own effort, showing situational awareness and humility.
Comments on others not giving him credit for inventing the Candygram, indicating awareness of achievements though possibly hinting at frustration.
Accepts pie from elderly woman despite earlier insult and responds politely.
Assures elderly woman to keep her visit secret, showing confidentiality.
Graciously accepts laurel wreath and thanks Howard Johnson.
Responds with good-natured humor to Howard's suggestion about the wreath.
Politely interacts with Barber with thanks and accepts offer for haircut and shave.
Responds with brief, friendly answers; no indication of coldness or hostility.
Boasts to Jim about becoming an underground success.
Responds politely and with gratitude to the townspeople's gestures despite previous insults.
Accepts gifts and favors with confidence and humor, demonstrating social savvy and wit.
Acknowledges the barber's unusual offer of a haircut at 4 AM with the confident reply 'Solid.', showing easy adaptability and control of the situation.
Mentions to Jim that he is becoming a 'big underground success' in town, indicating awareness of his growing influence and effectiveness.
Accepts a private meeting invitation from Lili and brings a red rose as a gift.
Mumbles about losing his hat after it is crushed by Leopold, showing a small moment of vulnerability and attachment.
Receives a secret note from Lili and decides to follow up on it, displaying confidence and awareness in a potentially risky social situation.
Calmly interacts with Leopold and Lili, handing over his hat even as it is destroyed, showing composure and tact.
Mumbles about losing his hat after Leopold crushes it, indicating a brief moment of minor frustration but quickly maintaining professionalism.
Makes a lighthearted joke about the kerosene lamp glare, showing ease and a relaxed demeanor.
Politely tells Lili she is sucking his arm, communicating discomfort in a direct but not hostile way.
Declines more schnitzengruber and hints at leaving for chores, maintaining boundaries and responsibility.
Makes a witty comment about eliminating the glare in the dark room, showing quick observation and humor.
Politely sets boundaries during conversation with Lili, indicating self-control and clear communication.
Declines further food and excuses himself responsibly to attend to chores, demonstrating good self-management and reliability.
Splashes water on Mongo to wake him up and then frees him from chains.
Urges Mongo to leave the jail after freeing him.
Rejects Lili's emotional plea to stay, telling her she's making a spectacle of herself.
Takes the writ from Jim and studies it carefully, showing awareness of legal matters.
Freed Mongo by splashing water on him, prompting Mongo to break chains and earn his loyalty.
Allows Mongo to stay despite telling him to leave, showing patience and ability to handle unpredictable allies.
Makes a joke about inventing pornography; shows humor but possibly distracts from focus.
Dismisses Lili when she clings to him and makes a scene, maintaining composure but potentially insensitivity.
Suggests investigating the railroad construction site proactively by sneaking out to snoop.
Maintains confident tone and reminds characters of his sheriff status when challenged.
Plans timing with the stage's arrival and relates it to eating horses, indicating resourcefulness and wit.
Responds to Charlie's surprise with humor and confidence, showing social skill and assurance.
Introduces Jim as his friend, shows camaraderie.
Is embraced and celebrated by railroad workers, indicating acceptance and possible positive relationships.
Confidently asserts himself as the duly appointed sheriff of Rock Ridge.
Maintains a calm and friendly demeanor introducing Jim to others.
Receives enthusiastic support from railroad workers, indicating leadership and respect.
No indication of hesitation or confusion in interactions with others.
Corrects Taggart firmly but without aggression, asserting his authority as sheriff.
Holds gun on Taggart and his men but encourages them to applaud the Waco Kid, showing humor and easing tension.
Confidently asserts his authority as sheriff despite racist provocation.
Calmly holds off Taggart's men with his gun while they are in pain from their own gunfire malfunctions.
Commands the situation by directing sarcastic applause to the Waco Kid when others are stunned.
Rides into the outskirts of Rock Ridge and observes wagons and buckboards being loaded, noticing the town's reaction and preparing accordingly.
Asks what is happening and seeks information about the townspeople leaving.
Recognizes the poster as a desperate act and shows concern for the town.
Plea for 24 hours to save Rock Ridge, demonstrating commitment and hopefulness.
Suggests getting closer to the target after observing the situation.
Allows himself to be physically displayed by Jim as a potential victim to the Ku Klux Klanners without immediate resistance or escape attempt.
Expresses enjoyment of a dramatic event with Jim, showing camaraderie.
Uses humor to lighten a grim situation (dreary voice about cactus), showing a bond with Jim.
Steps forward to take part in risky deception, indicating loyalty and courage.
Jumps into the water with others, participates in communal baptism scene.
Punches Cutthroat unconscious to protect self and Jim.
Engages in horse theft with Jim, rides off despite protest.
Quietly wakes Charlie and reassures him by saying 'it's me, it's me...Bart' to avoid startling him.
Quickly covers Charlie's mouth to prevent him from being heard while still allowing brief communication.
Gives clear instructions to Charlie about rallying others and gathering supplies, showing leadership but not explicitly friendly or warm.
Tells Charlie to say goodbye after instructions, showing a touch of personal connection.
Acts pragmatically and efficiently throughout, focused on survival and escaping enemies.
Outruns Taggart and his men by running like lightning, showing physical capability and quick thinking.
Strategically instructs Charlie to secretly gather supplies and coordinate a meeting, displaying planning and leadership.
Uses stealth and careful communication to avoid alerting enemies, indicating situational awareness and skill.
Shows calm and control while handling a tense situation with Charlie, suggesting confidence and command.
Reassures townspeople by explaining the plan clearly and confidently despite confusion.
Tells townspeople to trust him and rides off to lead them.
Demonstrates leadership by organizing people and resources to build a decoy town.
Tells Howard to grease the wagon wheel to stop it from squeaking, showing attention to practical details.
Calmly instructs the townspeople that they will build a perfect replica of Rock Ridge overnight to deceive the enemy, showing strategic thinking and confidence.
Responds to concerns about lack of time and people by revealing surprise reinforcements (railroad workers and materials), demonstrating resourcefulness and forethought.
Simply says 'Trust me' when questioned, without immediate explanation, which could be seen as confident but also risks causing confusion.
Offers land to railroad workers to help build the town, creating a cooperative community effort.
Rejects Olson Johnson's discriminatory demands by saying 'No deal.'
Encourages the townsfolk to roll up their sleeves and work together earnestly.
Successfully persuades railroad workers to help build the town by offering land, demonstrating negotiation skill and confidence.
Refuses to compromise with Olson Johnson's discriminatory demands, showing assertiveness and clear decision-making.
Motivates the crowd to work together and actively leads the effort to construct the town.
Keeps morale high and urges the group to speed up work as the sun rises, showing situational awareness and leadership.
Acknowledges the problem of no people in the replica town.
Encourages his men to work quickly and come up with an idea to slow down the attackers.
Uses humor with line 'A cute observation.' in response to Olson's concern.
Recognizes a critical problem (no people in the town replica) and articulates it clearly.
Develops a quick, practical plan to use dummies as decoys to slow down their enemies.
Takes initiative and leads others effectively by assigning tasks and directing a coordinated effort under time pressure.
Coordinating with others to set up a toll booth quickly, showing readiness and leadership.
Orders Mongo to bring something out, indicating command without evident warmth or friendliness.
Organizes and sets up a fake toll booth quickly and efficiently to trick the approaching horde.
Plans ahead anticipating the arrival of the horde and instructs others to hurry.
Successfully manages people (Jim, Howard, Samuel) to carry out the setup task.
Encourages townspeople to place dummies and organize a defense, working cooperatively with Jim.
Focuses on task of laying dynamite with Jim without hostile or dismissive behavior.
Organizes townspeople to place dummies strategically and directs Jim to start laying dynamite, demonstrating leadership and tactical planning.
Noticeably attentive and alert by observing the stagecoach approaching, showing situational awareness.
Encourages others and takes the lead during a tense moment, attempts to solve a problem collaboratively.
Maintains calm and tries to keep spirits up despite setbacks, addressing others with familiarity and friendliness.
Pushes plunger to set off dynamite, but nothing happens; quickly realizes the wire is broken.
Suggests shooting from a distance to set off the dynamite manually, demonstrating quick thinking under pressure.
Leads and encourages townspeople to fight off the invaders with a spirited war-whoop attack.
Commands and leads townspeople in a coordinated attack after the fake town explodes, showing strategic initiative.
Uses the explosion as a signal to finish off the enemy decisively, demonstrating confidence and control.
Fights back to back with Jim, effectively knocking out bad guys despite taking a punch.
Responds to being punched with a hollow voice before quickly retaliating and knocking out his attacker.
Comments to Jim with a sense of humor and awareness of their situation during chaotic fighting.
Picks up pie and smashes it into Lyle's face during fight.
Spots Hendley Lamarr sneaking out and chases after him.
Spots Lamarr sneaking out and immediately pursues him on horseback, showing quick reaction and decisiveness.
Throws away guns and suggests settling conflict with fists, indicating willingness to engage directly rather than escalate violence.
Engages in a physical fight resulting in the death of Lamarr.
Ties his horse to a parking meter confidently before approaching the theatre.
Throws away his guns and chooses to settle a dispute with his fists, showing confidence and control.
Quickly reacts to being fired upon by hurling himself to the ground, rolling over, picking up his six-shooter, and firing all in one motion.
Offers a sincere, somewhat humorous comment about Hedley Lamarr's death, showing casual openness with Jim.
Encourages Jim to join him to check out the end of the flick, indicating friendly inclusion.
Politely declines the town's request to stay, explaining his mission to help others in need.
Admits to the townspeople that he was exaggerating about needing to leave, showing honesty and a lighthearted side.
Slaps Charlie’s hand off roughly while riding past, a dismissive non-verbal gesture.
Remains calm and makes a dry, quick-witted remark at the death of Hedley Lamarr, showing presence of mind under tension.
Decides to leave the town after completing his work, demonstrating confident self-assessment and focus on his mission.
Expresses a sense of purpose and understanding about his role in fighting injustice in the West, indicating intelligence and clarity about his goals.
Admits candidly that he is leaving because things are getting dull, showing honesty but possibly undermining the heroic image and leaving abruptly.
Pledges himself confidently to Lili and addresses the townsfolk with a wave of his hat.
Stares at Lili's bosom and makes a flippant comment.
Calmly and casually interacts with Jim, inviting him to ride along, showing social ease and confidence.
Rides off into the sunset with Jim, stays alert and together they engage with the environment (e.g. noticing stagecoach and limousine).
